title: Doorknob Levers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was scheduled to have bilateral carpal tunnel surgery and wanted to have lever style doorknobs, so I created these levers to fit the doorknobs that are in my house. 
My surgery was successfully performed on 10/22/15 and the levers were really helpful during the first few days of my recovery.
The 47mm lever has a slight taper to fit a "tulip" style knob. The 51mm lever has a more square profile to fit a flat style knob. See the pictures of my knobs for clarification.
The levers have a small lip on the inner edge of the hole to help keep the lever properly positioned on the knob, place the lever on the knob with the small lip out. 
UPDATE - I just updated the levers to allow the screw to be on the top of the handle when installed on left-hinge doors - not upside-down like in my pictures.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25 or .30

Infill:

25%

I used a 1" long #8 x 32 machine screw (link to screws), washer and nut to clamp the lever to the knob. The nut is held in place by the hex-hole, so you can install the levers using only a screwdriver. No tape or adhesive was necessary on my knobs, you may need some on yours if the levers don't tighten securely. Be sure to place the lever on the knob properly, with the hole lip facing away from the door. The levers may be placed in any position on the knob that works best for the intended user, pointing up, down, towards the hinges, or on the inside of the door, pointing away from the hinges.

description.header: I designed these levers in Tinkercad.

description.text:
Some fun with simple gears...
This is my geared 3 bladed flip open star.
This started as a test to see what minimum spec's I could achieve with the Up! Mini.
Hope you like it!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2L7dX9VNdZs

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Higher is better

Infill:

as dense as possible

Start by placing three 3/8" 2-56 pan head screws into the gear so that the heads fit into the recesses.
Place the gear in the blade housing with the three grooves cut into it, the screws will protrude through it. With the gear facing up and threads down turn the gear fully clockwise and then place the blades in the closed position.
Put on the other blade housing and use three 1/4" 2-56 pan head screws and nuts to hold the blade housing together.
The blades fit snug to keep them from opening accidentally. The pieces may need a little sanding to get the release tension the way you want it.
Put on the cap with the square cutout and use a 1/4" 2-56 pan head screw to hold it on.
The hole is set to allow the screw to tap itself if you don't have a 2-56 tap. Be sure not to over-tighten the screw.
Put the cap with the three holes on over the protruding screws and use a 1/2" 2-56 pan head screw to hold it on. Again it will self tap if you don't have one.
Have fun.

Spiral bevel gears (conical, helical), proof of concept Look at :
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_bevel_gear
for some theory.
Actually my naming of these files is wrong, the gears ar not hypoid !
This means that the rotational axes of these two gears do cross through one point in space. Gcode generated with netfabb-Ultimaker edition, Martijn's build-style, 0.15mm layer height.
Printed on my (standard) Ultimaker, speed 250%, fan on (great machine !) NB: the teeth were decreased in size somewhat to account for the fact that Ultimaker/netfabb produces parts that are almost exactly 0.3mm too big in x- and y-direction (z-direction is fine). Simply scaling the parts up or down (too much) would render the teeth too small or too big, respectively. NB 2: due to the nature of the ProE module I used the default Csys got rotated by the same angle that the teeth are pivoted, 45Â°. Rotate the STL (back) by the same angle and you should be fine.

Print (0.15mm layer worked fine for me), consider re-drilling (straight) 2.8mm (~ core diameter of M3) holes into the knee, assemble with 3 M3 bolts, turn endlessly (hopefully).
Printing them one after another eliminates almost all 'stringing' (using netfabb).

A couple of years ago a friend introduced me to fantasy cosplay, and the gatherings in at Haarzuilen en Arken in the Netherlands. Now, if you think cosplay is stupid... move along... look at another of the many wonderful designs on this site, 'cause tthis is Thing is going to drive the geekiness needle of the scale.
Having played World of Warcraft quite a bit, i came to love the Warlock class. So i came up with the idea of cosplaying a Warlock at one of the comming events. But what's a Warlock without a demon? Right: naked...
Of all the demons a warlock can summon in WoW, i think the Imp is the coolest. But no costume could ever approach the looks of a WoW Imp, it's just physically impossible. So: why not build a Robot-Imp?
I've been running around with the idea quite a while now, but what pushed me over the edge is discovering the videos (and website) of James Bruton from XRobots (check out his website: http://xrobots.co.uk/). I'm starting this project at about the same time as he is starting work on his 'Ultron' android. Since the Imp and James' Ultron share a lot of design goals, i'm sure i'll be learning a lot from his videos.
Obviously this project is going to be in the 'WIP' state for a long time to come. And doesn't involve just printed parts but a good deal of electronics and mechanics as well. Never the less, i am already putting completed parts up here. Both to have a central repository of them, and... i would LOVE to hear your ideas! author: Shrodix

title: Honda Civic Del Sol Battery Tie Down

description.text:
I went down to O' Riley to get a battery tie-down for my Del Sol and all they had was this floppy rubber thing that was too big.  I went ahead and bought the kit to get the "J-hooks" (I have since discovered they also sell the hooks on their own) and then I designed and printed my own crossmember.  This crossmember is sized to fit the optima battery in my car, but seeing as the battery fits the tray almost perfectly it should work with other batteries as well, and if you need a little bigger, just scale your print settings a little.  
The V1 version is the version I printed and install in my car.  I had to drill out the holes a little to get them to fit the J-hooks (ABS tends to shrink a little), for this reason it might be worth adding a couple of passes to your wall thicknesses in your print settings.  The V2 version has slightly larger holes (which should forgo the drilling) and has longer side braces to allow for greater stabilization (which is probably over kill as the V1 works pretty well in my experience).  I provide both as either may be a good jumping off point for your own specific application.  
This item should be super easy to print (I only printed this item once to get it to work), and you would likely get away with PLA, though because of the fact this is an automotive application ABS is a better choice. The part is designed with structural architecture to aid in its resilience and rigidity, and should be a very capable part, but of course, use at your own risk, I make no claims regarding suitability for any given application and I am not liable for any issues that arise from its use or failure.
I designed these items in 123D Design. 
Note on usage, even though this part was specifically created for my Del Sol and battery, it will very likely work with other civics, or other small cars that use the same size battery.  My design has a battery allowance of 129mm.  So if your battery width is close to that size, you should be able to make this brace work.

title: Ikea hack: Mulig shelving unit proRoomba
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Makit presents…our first Ikea hack, make a Mulig shelving unit proRoomba
Have you ever wondered why there is furniture that is not proRoomba?
Why have a Roomba if it can't go under our furniture?
My purpose is to have a proRoomba home where my "personal assistant" (meaning roomba robot) can go under almost everything.
I recently bought an Ikea Mulig shelving unit and found out that it needed 20mm extra space in order for the Roomba to go under. So, I designed a simple leg that increases the clearance and that’s it, my Roomba goes down the shelves without any problem!
Isn't it awesome?

author: swalden

description.text:
A nifty mathematical object, sliced on the diagonal to expose the internal structure and permit printing without rafts, support, or horizontal spans.  
Added 1- and 2-level sponges as well. When printed smaller, I think the 2-level sponge comes out very nicely.

You can create your own variants using NetFabb Basic as follows:  
Create a Menger Sponge (it's a primitive)  
Rotate Z axis by 45 degrees, then Y axis by 54.73560912600694 degrees.  
Slice off a corner by cutting along the Z plane (make fine adjustments by 0.1mm in the slicing dialog to get it just right)  
Remove the bottom segment, creating the flat base.  
Export as STL, and resize in your slicer.  
For small prints, a 1- or 2-level sponge is probably best

title: reprappro mendel3 with diamond hotend parts

description.text:
All parts I have printed while bulding my (almost complete) reprappro mendel 3.
(https://reprappro.com/documentation/mendel-3/). It´s not finished, so I may add more files later. I decided to replace the hotends with a diamond nozzle from http://reprap.me,
and I use machanical endstops/servo probing instead of the optical endstop used by reprappro. About the files: The bar clamp is remixed from one of the reprappro clamps. I used it to mount a fan. The Fan guard is created with Moon Cactus customizer http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=128718 The 8mm igusbushing was made in tinkercad, I printed it in nylon. Seems to work. The lcd box is a remix of scarous - I just added mounts. Print it with supports. The back plate and button can be found in his http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:684778 The plate to lower the nozzle was created in tinkercad, I had to lower the nozzle in order to fit the servo on the back. The reprappro mendel 3 diamond hotend x carriage was remixed from twisterss http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:129202 - I added holes to fit the diamond_shield_cooler_blower found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:720520
(I would have added the "nozzle lower plate" on the diamond_shield if I was to do it again.) The servo arm was created from the scad made by Wayne Weng http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:630632 The servo mounting plate was made in tinkercad The Y motor spacer is another reprappro part I that I remixed in order to mount the Y motor. It may need some spacers. Electronics box here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1095580 The zip file contains all (unchanged) parts I have printed: Some were a bit difficult to find.
From reprappro.com:
1010_Frame vertex with foot (mirrored)_2pcs.STL

title: Fabrikator extra fan clip for E3D hot end

description.text: If you have fitted an E3D hot end (or similar) you can remount the Fabrikator part fan using this clip. Just punch out the magnets from the old hot end cover and push them into this clip. Now use one of the M3 screws from the cover to mount the clip to the bottom right 3 mm hole on the extruder plate. Now just pop the fan on and you are done.

description.text: Designed to be used with Adafruit's LCD shield kit with buttons (one example: http://www.adafruit.com/products/772) and Carlon electrical box (P/N E989NNJ). I purchased my Carlon 4" x 4" x 2" box from Home Depot for about $7.00. The box does not have any holes in it (for sensor wires or power), so you'll have to add those yourself or make another box. To activate the reset button you will need to use a paperclip or similar small pin. One STL has text on the buttons and the other does not. If you want to make your own box, the overall height x width is 101 mm x 101 mm and the holes are 3.625 in x 3.625 in center-to-center.

Sliced @ 0.2mm
50% fill Need:
(1) faceplate
(4) M3 x 10 mm screws
(4) M3 nuts (optional, I just threaded into board because PCB diameter was small)
(1) Carlon box (or equivalent)

comments.author: foster182

comments.text: If it were an exact mirror, it would be easy.  I was looking at the Adafruit's Raspberry Pi LCD + keypad and noticed several key differences.  (1) Select button is not an exact mirror, (2) contrast potentiometer is in a different location, (3) the main board looks to be a different size.  The last difference is a problem.  My design uses a pair of "clips" to help secure the main board to faceplate.  Without these, the button "pushes" were not consistent.  So in order to properly modify the design, I would need to have one of these boards so I could tweak the faceplate accordingly.  Maybe you can convince Adafruit so send me one. :).

description.text:
Me and my family love asian food, so of course we use a lot of chopsticks (in fact my Dad eats everything with them, including pizza) and we keep all of our chopsticks in a metal cup. First problem, after sitting on their tips for long periods of time, the paint and wood get worn away leaving bits of chopstick in our food.
+How this helps+ since this organizer holds the chopsticks in their center, the tips are left hanging in the air, eliminating wear. Second problem, having tons of chopsticks together in a cup or drawer gets them all mixed up so you have a really hard time organizing them.
+How this helps+ Because all of the chopsticks are held next to each other you can organize them into sets of two. This holder has six holes because I have three people in my family, but this can be lengthened or shortened as desired.
Print; drill, tape, or glue onto your wall; profit!

title: FiGo - Dog Wheelchair
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: ** FiGO has been updated and published here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1397964 Wheelchairs for domestic animals are very expensive and often inaccessible to many pet owners. This is not always the most welcoming solution for individuals who need a pet wheelchair for their animals at short notice, on a budget, at a remote location, or perhaps for temporary purposes. This project empowers individuals to build their pet’s wheelchair with the combination of digital fabrication (3D printing) and traditional making. This device uses parametrically designed 3D printed joint pieces that fit into acrylic tubing, which can be easily customized to the dog for both fit and style purposes. This is currently my second prototype. I redesigned the pieces in this second prototype to be more geometric so that they are much easier to print. I wanted to make sure that all materials used in the fabrication of this chair would be widely accessible to anyone regardless of your location. The wheelchair consists of roller blade wheels, standard skate bearings, screws, acrylic tubing, straps, and 3D printed joint pieces. The wheelchair project started as a design for Anne Murray, a 7 year old French Bulldog. I made sure that the wheelchair accurately reflected her personality as described by her very caring owner Martha J. I printed it in bright purple and included glitter in the clear acrylic tubing used to frame the design.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20 to .30

Infill:

20-25%

Notes: Print 2x of each piece (A,B,C,D,E) if you want to print the pieces with the exact outer diameter of the acrylic tubing (0.75") I have suggested, I have made those pieces available as well ie. "pieceA_exact.stl". Since there is some slight warping that occurs while printing, you may be more comfortable printing in the adjusted size that is slightly larger to accommodate the acrylic tubing with more ease "pieceA_adjusted.stl. Just make sure to choose one format and remain consistent with all pieces. With exact sizes, you will likely need a heat gun to heat up the piece and then quickly insert it into the tube. This will fuse the two pieces together. With adjusted sizes, you might want to use glue (gorilla glue works well) to ensure the tubes will not be loose. This may not be an issue if you have a dog that weighs less than 10 pounds. My client was a 30 pound Frenchie!

Assembling the Dog Wheelchair I used 0.75" inner diameter acrylic tubing to make the frame for the dog wheelchair. These 3D printed parts simply support this structure. The length of each tube will depend on your dog's width and height. There are three different lengths of acrylic (or aluminum) tubing needed: 2x Acrylic tube the same as your dog's width.
2x Acrylic tube the height of your dog minus the radius of your chosen wheel, minus 1"
2x Acrylic tube the length of your dog from their belly to their tail, minus 2" I have created a simple google spreadsheet that does these calculations for you as you input your dogs measurements. I am working on a web application that has this function, but this will do for the meantime! https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1OUDn9DBQ-ixo-nfdue-AFACkzlDrC4GsDhREl2hxNsc/edit?usp=sharing I also purchased two roller blade wheels and two standard skate bearings (the wheels pictured below were part of prototype #1, see photos above for new wheels). In order to support the wheels I used two screws [(1/4 - 20) x 3"] fastened with a nut to the bearing and acorn nut to the 3D printed piece E. Finally I purchased one strap from my local hardware store that is placed into piece D to support where the back legs (flanks) meet the body of the dog. I also purchased two velcro straps that feed through piece C to attach directly to your dog's existing harness. I am still working on a way to improve the connection of the piece to the harness! Assembly diagram Acrylic tubing

I designed this wheelchair using OpenSCAD so that the models can be adjusted to the size of tubing you have access to. I'm still currently working on this document (it is rather messy and needs to be polished) but I will make it accessible to everyone once it is prepared. This way you don't have to use 0.75" inner diameter acrylic tubing exclusively (even though I have tested many sizes and concluded that it is the best size for strength/weight ratio).
I am still heavily prototyping this design. I welcome all of your comments and suggestions! Thanks!!

comments.text: I just wanted to say thank you so much for designing this and you are an awesome person. I have a 12 year old Bassett Hound who are prone to back problems. Out of nowhere yesterday, her back legs went limp and she could no longer use her back legs. After the visit to the emergency vet, they said it could be a ruptured disc. My option was to either put her into emergency surgery for $4000, or go home and crate rest her, carrying her out to use the bathroom by hand, while using a blanket slung beneath her back legs to use the bathroom. This could be for anywhere from 6-8 weeks, to 6 months, to maybe never a full recovery. I've been doing the sling thing for just one day, while I've been 3D printing out the parts and sourcing the wheels and acrylic tubing, and my arms are killing me from how heavy my Bassett is (prob 40 lbs). I have to say your design is brilliant and I can't wait to get mine built for my baby. I will take pics and report back, but just wanted to say I can already tell this is going to help her get around so good, and great call on the rollerblade wheels, those are gonna be butter smooth!

Ok, this is a tough one. This treasure chest is printed in one piece!
You definitely should be good friends with your MakerBot when printing this. ABS warping is a big problem. The few lucky ones with PLA on their desk definitely have the advantage here... Anyway, you might give it a shot. As usual with my quirky objects, Skeinforge is moaning and groaning when processing it. But if you configure "Carve" to use "unproven meshes" and ignore all warnings, you should get a printable gcode file :) The attached gcode is the one I used for printing the treasure chest on the photo. It's suitable for MakerBots with a .5mm nozzle. There's also a short video on this on YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wtoLPj_YOkA

• Print the object
  • Remove the raft and the two support pylons
  • Store your treasures
    • [UPDATE 06/26/2011: The attached gcode is (as the whole object) from October 2009. There was no TOM then, only Makerbot Cupcakes with MK3 extruders. The pre-generated gcode is (and stays) here for historical reference. If you own a newer Cupcake or TOM, generate your own gcode from the STL]

description.text:
Post with working links on my blog: http://eclecti.cc/bytes/reprap-controlled-time-lapse-photography YouTube example videos:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T3j5oXpqWCk
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GFZXgxcfdHQ While capturing the time-lapse last week, John and I ran into two irritating issues. The first is that the moving platform causes the object being printed to come in and out of the focal plane of the camera and makes for a jarring video. The second is that because the interval between photos is constant, some large and slow layers will have multiple shots taken while several consecutive quick layers can be skipped entirely. The solution to both of these is to dynamically remote trigger the camera from the printer. I wrote a Skeinforge photograph plugin that inserts a new G-code command, M240, which tells the printer to trigger a photograph. The module offers three modes. End of Layer, as demonstrated by Yoda below, is the simplest. It takes one picture at the start of the first layer and then another at the end of each layer of the print, resolving only the second of the aforementioned issues. Corner of Layer takes a picture at the minimum Y,X of each layer. Least Change between Layers tries to take shots that are as close as possible to each other from layer to layer. I had the most visually interesting results with the last setting, as shown in the Flower print above. The module can be downloaded from github, and installation instructions are included within its text. The other half of the control scheme is triggering the camera from the RepRap. Since I didnâ€™t want to risk coupling my T2i directly to the printer, I went for emulating a Canon RC-1 Remote, which has been thoroughly reverse engineered. The hardware is simply an 850nm infrared LED in series with a 180 ohm resistor connected to one of the I/O pins on the Arduino Mega. I chose pin 23 because I could solder to it without pulling my RAMPS board off. The software side is equally simple. For this, I forked the excellent Sprinter firmware to respond to M240 and send the correct pulse over the IR LED. My fork is on github, but the diff that adds M240 support is the interesting bit.
Photograph plugin and firmware on github: https://github.com/nrpatel/Sprinter

description.text: 08/07/2013 - This has been superseded by Version 2 of the extruder calibration tool found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:114614 This is a tool I designed to help with the calibration of the extruder on the Felix Printer. I was frustrated with inaccuracy of marking filament and trying to measure with my callipers. This helps by providing two flat surfaces that the vernier callipers can easily measure between. It is simple to install and remove without having to remove any filament from the extruder. Just push the filament into the top piece and start the calibration process as per normal, measuring between the top and bottom as you go. There are still a couple of things I still need to fix on this design, but works as is. It is designed for 1.75mm filament and has a very tight fit so may need some adjustment by filing the push fit until a snug fit for the filament is is achieved until I fix this problem. This was designed for the Felix v2 Printer (http://www.felixprinters.com) but should work with an other model printer.
You will need to add support when printing, it's minimal.

This is a knob cap that helps twist for your lamp switch knob. Some lamp is too tight to turn or sometimes you just have a wet hand. This cap snaps right on to a standard size knob and makes the turn much easier. Print this with glow in the dark ABS will make the switch even easier to find. The hole is 6.5 mm and the diameter of the whole cap is 18 mm.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20% - 80%

Notes: The one I printed was ABS. The size doesn't matter that much since the hole is a hex shape. It is 6.5 mm in diameter which fit a standard knob from 6 to 7 mm. The length is set to 10 mm which is also adjustable.

Install To put this on you need a little bit pressure to push it in. If your knob is larger, you may consider twist it off of your lamp and then use a book or hammer to smash it in. Since you are going to use it a lot you need to make sure it is tight. So don't try to adjust the hole if its not too small.
This is made in 3ds max with ruler eye-balled measurement. The max file is attached if you want to adjust the size.

A model of my lombar spine extracted from ~100 CT scan slices. Perfect for any home's decor!
You're looking at an otherwise healthy 23-year-old male's spine with a slight disc herniation at L5-S1 and bulging discs/stenosis at L3-L4 and L4-L5. The L5-S1 level is the first disc gap at the bottom of the model. Damage was caused by a car accident.
CT scan DICOM data extracted with Invesalius. Invesalius model cleaned with Meshmixer. Base added using 123D Design.
This is a sloppy model with a lot of unnecessary internal walls. Took around 5 hours to print on a Prusa i3 w/ Lite6 hot end, 50mm/s infill speed, 30mm/s shell speed, 20% infill, 0.8mm shell thickness, 0.4mm nozzle. Supports and brim recommended to help with overhangs and lifting.

After test printing this I decided to beef up all the thicknesses, especially on the connecting tabs. If you downloaded an earlier version please download again. I have also eliminated the symbol lens into a single flat lens panel that slides behind the symbol cut outs...it just makes more sense. This is a light cycle baton from Tron Legacy. It is 1 to 1 in scale and is designed so that lighting can be added to light up the center symbols as well as the end cap lights with 3mm LEDs. There are many variations of this prop, stunt ones, display ones as well as costume ones. I took the elements I liked best from all the different variations to create my own. I mainly followed the production drawings and combined that with the look of the stunt baton. I'd print the symbols and End Cap Lights out in translucent filament so that you can light it up with LEDs. This is sized correctly to 11 5/8" and is intended to be worn on the side of your lower leg or shin. See you on the Game Grid fellow program!
Parts were built in TinkerCad and sized according to pre-production drawings. It slices well in MakerBot software and I've successfully printed one on an MBot clone printer.

remixed_from.title: Jhead Compact Extruder for i3 Rework

title: Modified Jhead Compact Extruder for I3 Rework

description.text:
I love the Jhead Compact Extruder for i3 Rework by Mak-a-face, but I had a few issues with it. The hobb on my extruder bolt was too deep to work with the default configuration. I took the 1.75mm version and modified it to support 3mm. I also adjusted the mounting location to be 2mm lower because it cracked at this point from a thin wall. The original blower should work. All of the original files will work. The cutout around the motor has been widened slightly because the screw on my gear was sticking out too much. Uses the 1.75 guide from the original thing by Mak-a-face EDIT 10/27/15: I updated the files. I had the wrong one uploaded, which was an additional 3mm in height.
New files are an extra 2mm as they should be. I adjusted the mount for the shroud so that all original parts should work. Still need to use the 1.75mm guide. title: Child Safety Stove Knob Protectors - customizable

description.text:
This is something I came up with to help keep small hands from turning the knobs on the stove.  Either turning the burners on and burning down the house or turning the burners up and scorching dinner.   The stove knobs are protected all around by a wall of plastic.  The knob-protectors are linked together in groups of two to keep the child from rotating the protector around.  This piece is held in place by the plastic nut behind the knob.
The piece is designed in OpenSCAD and is customizable.  There is a setting for diameter of the inside hole, the knob's diameter, thickness, knob spacing, the diagonal cutout, etc.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: I printed mine is it is in the stl. No support or rafts is needed. I used ABS due to its location and it will likely be getting hot food spilled on it. This is an item designed to protect your family and your house, so it made sense to use 100% infill rather than trying to save $0.50 and a half hour with lower infill.

Remove the knobs from the stove.
Remove the nuts (and any washers) behind the nuts that are on the knob shaft.
Test fit this piece.
If everything looks good, assemble the stove as it was before, but with this piece now sandwiched between the front face of the stove and the nuts/washers behind the knobs. remove knobs remove nuts and washers test fit all parts reassemble

title: Tamiya tank tread chassis mod for dual gearbox

description.text:
Size: 180mm x 60mm x 4mm (width at gearbox mount is 70mm)
Main Body for use with the Tamiya tank tread hobby kit. The rear holes have been adapted for the dual gearbox. The "Tam_Pictured" stl is the file that was printed and used in the photos. The difference is that the gearbox is 5mm further forward in "Tam_Pictured", and there are two small mounting holes on the back. "Tamiya_Mount" has the gearbox 5mm further back, and loses the rear holes, but can better handle some tread configurations.
I have also added four extra mounting holes for mounting extra components to the base (micro servo, standoffs, etc). I will be adding an Arduino/servo mount as soon as I get those finished.
It just happened that the original screws that came with my kit hold snugly, but M3 machine screws/nuts should also work.
EDIT: uploaded pic with a more "tank" tread configuration.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes: I printed at .2mm layer height and 60% infill. It seems to be plenty strong at these settings. The print is 4mm thick. This was to accommodate the standoffs/nuts I have. If you would like it thicker, you should gain 1mm for every 25% added to the Z axis.

comments.text: That is the dual gearbox setup. Each side moves independently. There's actually two smaller shafts inside the housing, so moving only one side or the other (or both in opposite directions), will rotate the vehicle.

This is an Airsoft speed loader designed for six .38 rounds.

You will need:
Four 1/2" 2-56 pan head screws- get at www.mcmastercarr.com
I highly recommend using a 2-56 tap
One common pen spring,
One .177 cal BB
Begin by lightly sanding the interior of the cylinder, it it critical that the surface that rubs on the shell be very smooth.
Tap the 3 outer holes in the cylinder.
Tap the center rising post
With the riser, place the small post into the small center hole in the cylinder in the side with the three small holes.
With the cylinder on the table place the collar over the center post. Be sure the turn-stop on the collar faces up.
Screw the collar to the cylinder. Place the cylinder on the table with the turn-stop closest to you. Turn the center post until the raised side is perpendicular to both the collar turn-stop and the BB seat and the raised half of the post is on the right.
Cut your pen spring to approximately .6"
Insert the spring into the small hole on the outer edge of the knob with the finished edge of the spring pointing out.
Align the BB on the collar with the spring while placing the knob on the post.
Screw the knob to the post.
If you have aligned everything properly you will not be able to see the BB and you will get a satisfying "click" when turning the knob. The BB serves to keep the shells locked in place until you turn the knob.
Because some shells have slightly different tolerances a little filing of the shell holding arms may be necessary.

description.text:
This is my attempt at maximizing the build envelope of a 3D printer using most of the hardware from a prusa (mine is an I2) ie smooth rods, bearings, threaded rod etc. This has roughly 268x290x260 (200x200 on the x and y if using standard bed) working area using the prusa I2 hardware and can be scaled to what ever size needed based on the smooth rods used (within reason 8mm rods can only be so long). It has a cantilevered z-axis with a counter balance load design that moves with the z-axis. It is a coreXY non crossing belt design, meaning it has two separate equal length belts and cause no wear from odd angles on the belt. Bowden design, and I will be uploading the dwg files for the wooden case I'm making for it for an enclosed chamber. X-axis and z-axis endstop mounts are integrated and included y axis I used this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:71488 for the y-axis. The frame is built using common inch aluminum extrusion found at most any hardware stores and the sizes needed for a prusa hardware setup are shown in the image with the iso views in the attached pdf file. Also in one of the pdfs is how the motor mount corners are assembled, they are done this way to remove all axial force off of the motor which should mean less current is needed to drive the motor as friction is reduced. I have included the printer as an stl so its easy to look at. will require modification to two threaded rods (listed below as optional because you can have a hardware store/machine shop cut to size for you)
427mm threaded rod (mine was cut from a prusa I2 frame rod) (rear z axis)
401mm threaded rod (again cut from a prusa I2 frame rod) (front z axis) print 2 of bottom corners A and B and 1 of everything else (2 of the feed tube ball join holders if you plan on an enclosure)

description.header: extra hardware needed(if you already have a prusa I2)
description.text:
10 additional 608 bearing(can be found a most sports outfitter store, skate shops, ski shops etc)
some m3 (or ansi equivelent) self tapers
minimum 40 1/2 m8 bolts with matching nuts.(haven't counted all yet)
acetone(aka abs glue)
4x 8mm bore gt2 20T pulleys(metal recommended)
2x 1650mm belts (measured at 1634 but nice to have some to pull on for tension clip)
1x 102mm length GT2 51T closed loop belt.(can be diy sown but easier to buy)

description.header: Otpional(if you don't want or can't cut the m8 threaded rods)
description.text:
427mm threaded rod (mine was cut from a prusa I2 frame rod) (rear z axis)
401mm threaded rod (again cut from a prusa I2 frame rod) (front z axis)

11/10/15 updated all the corners(doesn't effect motor mounts or bearing holder) and z-axis parts that attach to the aluminum. I found after printing they required a lot of sanding to fit so I adjusted them to fit better. Also the bearing corners rear_corner_top_left/right have been modified to take a M8 bolt instead of the printed "rod" as it was found to not hold the tension of the two belts.
11/7/15   updated motor_corners to make it easier to fit a socket in for the motor bolts
10/30/15  Was asked for file in step, just finished uploading
10/21/15 Updated motor corners assembly to make it easy to assemble, So three parts in each corner,

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

.2

Infill:

40%

Notes: I personally do everything at .2 but you should be able to print all these parts at most resolutions as I tried to make them printer friendly, They will need to be rotated as invetor always rotates the x axis 90 degrees from what most slicers use.

title: raspberry pi camera and stand for printrbot simple metal

description.text:
This is a raspberry pi camera case and stand to mount on the left side of a printrbot simple metal. I'm in the process of designing hidden wiring system for the PSM and the camera stand is just one of the parts. As you can see from the last few pictures, it's gone through some revisions, with this being the final form.
The camera stand features a the hidden wire tunnel along the back. No wire hanging about loosely. The ball joint connector is very stiff, which makes it easy to point the camera in any direction. Lastly, the stand itself is pretty hefty, reducing any vibration and wobble from being recorded by the camera itself. I've included a screen shot of the view you get from the camera.
If you want the stand for the right side, just mirror the stand in your slicing app.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

18%

Notes: The ball joint requires a little support under it to keep it nice and round. Make sure that there are no supports inside the hidden wire tunnel. I printed this with with black PLA from Inland, no issues with the heated bed. Will report back if anything chances.

title: Loose Filament Spool Enhancement (based on the Spool Wall Mount)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Update: A new version of the enhancement plate (version with 'New' in the name): with grooves to keep the rubber band better in place (but is harder to print as of the needed bridging). Both enhancement plates are interchangeable and proper fit to the cones of my spool wall mount. Better clickable and removable with the updated cone form the spool wall mount. If you want a stronger fit turn it little as a bayonet catch. New a spacer part to have the proper distance between the cones. This is an enhancement to my Spool Wall Mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1051124) to handle loose filament. Simple click-fix it on one of the cones and you don't need to remove it for usual spools. The mechanism and design is heavily inspired by this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13395 Thank you murat! You have to print the Enhancement Plate and three of the forks. I uploaded the fork as single piece and grouped as two or three of them, depends our you building space. Additionally needed are three M4x16 countersunk screws (5/32" or US No.8, 5/8" length) and a rubber band. Be carefully by pressing the enhancement plate to the existing cone (-> instructions). See the handling on the pictures. You have to mount something between the cones to have enough horizontal space (can be the spacer part as attached to this thing or an empty toilet paper roll if nothing else available ;-) ). After entering the loose filament you pivoting the three forks 90 degrees to fix it. Enjoy your upgraded spool wall mount!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

75%

Notes: All in ABS (but PLA should would work, too):
  • Enhancement Plate: 2h30 - 3h00
  • Enhancement Forks: 1 piece in 0h30 - 0h45

Instructions:

  • Cleaning the parts and sanding the snap-on-pins to have smooth surfaces.

  • Carefully pressing one existing cone to the snap-on-pins of the enhancement plate. DO NOT CANT THE PIECES! Use a vise and something like this if possible (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1023770). You don't need to remove the enhancement plate for the use with regular rolls up to an inner diameter of 54mm (see picture). If you need to remove the enhancement carefully lever it parallel in small steps with a screw driver to not cant!

  • Mount the enhancement forks as on the pictures with M4x16 (5/32" or US No.8, 5/8" length) countersunk screws.

  • Use a rubber band.

Project: Advanced 3D prints Objectives An objective of this project is to learn how to print more advanced items on a 3D printer. Audiences 7th Grade or higher Preparations Some materials needed for this project are:
  • A 3D printer
  • Filament
  • Patience
    • Steps
  • Download one of the two files
  • Open file in slicing software

  • Export file to SD card
  • Calibrate printer
  • Print
  • Wait until print is done

title: ipad mini wall mount with changer cable

description.text:
My girlfriend needed a stopwatch for her darkroom photo development. She found an app for her ipad mini that supported multiple timers in one, with messages to remind her what step in the process she was at. Anyway, for it to be really usable she would need the ipad to be out of the way, preferabke hanging on the wall. 
I made this design to solve that problem. I have to say, I'm really impressed how well the ipad fits in. I doubt that apple could have designed it any better :)
I also fitted the original chager plug in the bottom. I hava printed the design both in ABS and PLA. The plug is really easy to fit in the ABS version, due to ABS have this slightly grease feel. The plug fit in really tight, so I have not mount the plug car for the two I mounted in our house.
